Legal_Issue: Whether the Officer's decision to award 22 points for education and refusal to exercise discretion was unreasonable
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant provided evidence that his Iranian medical degree equates to a master’s degree; Officer found insufficient evidence to support this claim
Decision_Outcome: Officer awarded 22 points, treating the credential as bachelor’s level
Burden_of_Proof: On the Applicant to demonstrate equivalence of foreign credential
Credibility_Factor: Lack of sufficient supporting documentation for degree equivalence
Legal_Rule: Officers may substitute point assessments if they do not reflect economic potential; education assessed based on local recognition (OP 6a)
Procedural_Issue: Procedural fairness in the officer’s assessment and decision-making process
Grounds_for_Claim: Unreasonable point assignment and refusal to exercise discretion
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Decision found to be procedurally fair
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicant's Iranian medical degree, lack of formal equivalency assessment
Applicant_Challenge: Contested the educational point assessment and discretionary refusal
Defendant_Response: Officer maintained decision due to insufficient evidence
Legal_Provision: Subsection 76(3) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Insufficient points for selection criteria, primarily education
Applicable_Process: Economic class immigration application under federal skilled worker category
Governing_Rule: Subsection 76(3) allows substitution of points if economic potential is not reflected
